Overall, this work introduces a promising strategy for automatically constructing Bayesian Networks by combining probabilistic knowledge extracted from LLMs with small amounts of real-world data. Additionally, we evaluate several prompting strategies for eliciting probabilistic knowledge from LLMs and establish the first comprehensive baseline for assessing LLM performance in extracting probabilistic knowledge.

item.title: Aligning Dialogue Agents with Global Feedback via Large Language Model Reward Decomposition
item.content:encoded:
large language model, reward decomposition, dialogue agents, session-level feedback, multimodal

Summary: The article introduces a reward decomposition framework for aligning dialogue agents using a large language model (LLM). The framework leverages the LLM's reasoning capabilities to infer fine-grained local rewards by decomposing global session-level feedback. The proposed models include a text-only variant where the LLM analyzes dialogue transcripts and a multimodal variant that incorporates behavioral cues such as pitch and facial affect expressed as natural language descriptions. These inferred turn-level rewards are used to fine-tune dialogue generation through reinforcement learning. The study compares the text-only and multimodal variants with existing reward decomposition methods and shows significant improvements in human evaluations of conversation quality. The results indicate that LLMs are effective reward decomposers, eliminating the need for manual reward shaping and detailed human feedback.
arXiv:2505.15922v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We propose a large language model based reward decomposition framework for aligning dialogue agents using only a single session-level feedback signal. We leverage the reasoning capabilities of a frozen, pretrained large language model (LLM) to infer fine-grained local implicit rewards by decomposing global, session-level feedback. Our first text-only variant prompts the LLM to perform reward decomposition using only the dialogue transcript. The second multimodal variant incorporates additional behavioral cues, such as pitch, gaze, and facial affect, expressed as natural language descriptions. These inferred turn-level rewards are distilled into a lightweight reward model, which we utilize for RL-based fine-tuning for dialogue generation. We evaluate both text-only and multimodal variants against state-of-the-art reward decomposition methods and demonstrate notable improvements in human evaluations of conversation quality, suggesting that LLMs are strong reward decomposers that obviate the need for manual reward shaping and granular human feedback.

item.title: Citation Parsing and Analysis with Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: global inequalities, knowledge circulation, citation networks, open-weight language models, research indexing Summary: - The article highlights the need for a tool to support journals in understanding how knowledge circulates globally to address inequalities in knowledge production and dissemination. - The absence of such a tool has led to a lack of information on networks of knowledge sharing in the Global South, resulting in the exclusion of researchers from indexing services. - The study investigates the use of open-weight language models to annotate manuscript citations in an indexable format. - Evaluations show that even basic language models can accurately identify components of citations, outperforming existing methods. - The findings suggest that post-training these models could lead to the development of small, robust citation parsing models that can improve research indexing, discovery, and metascientific research.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.15948v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: A key type of resource needed to address global inequalities in knowledge production and dissemination is a tool that can support journals in understanding how knowledge circulates. The absence of such a tool has resulted in comparatively less information about networks of knowledge sharing in the Global South. In turn, this gap authorizes the exclusion of researchers and scholars from the South in indexing services, reinforcing colonial arrangements that de-center and minoritize those scholars. In order to support citation network tracking on a global scale, we investigate the capacity of open-weight language models to mark up manuscript citations in an indexable format. We assembled a dataset of matched plaintext and annotated citations from preprints and published research papers. Then, we evaluated a number of open-weight language models on the annotation task. We find that, even out of the box, today's language models achieve high levels of accuracy on identifying the constituent components of each citation, outperforming state-of-the-art methods. Moreover, the smallest model we evaluated, Qwen3-0.6B, can parse all fields with high accuracy in $2^5$ passes, suggesting that post-training is likely to be effective in producing small, robust citation parsing models. Such a tool could greatly improve the fidelity of citation networks and thus meaningfully improve research indexing and discovery, as well as further metascientific research.

item.title: Training Step-Level Reasoning Verifiers with Formal Verification Tools
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Process Reward Models, Large Language Models, step-level error labels, formal verification, theorem proof Summary: Process Reward Models (PRMs) are gaining attention for providing feedback on reasoning by Large Language Models (LLMs). Two challenges are accurate step-level error labeling and PRMs limited to math problems. This paper introduces FoVer, which uses formal verification tools for automatic step-level error labeling on LLM responses for formal logic and theorem proof tasks. The synthesized dataset enables training PRMs without human annotation, leading to improved verification on diverse reasoning tasks. Results show cross-task generalization with FoVer-trained PRMs outperforming baseline and state-of-the-art models on various benchmarks. The FoVer dataset, models, and code are publicly available.

Summary: - PRMs provide feedback on LLM reasoning - FoVer addresses challenges of error labeling and generalizes PRMs to diverse tasks - FoVer uses formal verification tools for automatic error labeling - Synthesized dataset allows training PRMs without human annotation - Cross-task generalization observed with improved verification performance
arXiv:2505.15960v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Process Reward Models (PRMs), which provide step-by-step feedback on the reasoning generated by Large Language Models (LLMs), are receiving increasing attention. However, two key research gaps remain: collecting accurate step-level error labels for training typically requires costly human annotation, and existing PRMs are limited to math reasoning problems. In response to these gaps, this paper aims to address the challenges of automatic dataset creation and the generalization of PRMs to diverse reasoning tasks. To achieve this goal, we propose FoVer, an approach for training PRMs on step-level error labels automatically annotated by formal verification tools, such as Z3 for formal logic and Isabelle for theorem proof, which provide automatic and accurate verification for symbolic tasks. Using this approach, we synthesize a training dataset with error labels on LLM responses for formal logic and theorem proof tasks without human annotation. Although this data synthesis is feasible only for tasks compatible with formal verification, we observe that LLM-based PRMs trained on our dataset exhibit cross-task generalization, improving verification across diverse reasoning tasks. Specifically, PRMs trained with FoVer significantly outperform baseline PRMs based on the original LLMs and achieve competitive or superior results compared to state-of-the-art PRMs trained on labels annotated by humans or stronger models, as measured by step-level verification on ProcessBench and Best-of-K performance across 12 reasoning benchmarks, including MATH, AIME, ANLI, MMLU, and BBH. The datasets, models, and code are provided at https://github.com/psunlpgroup/FoVer.

item.title: Pre-training Large Memory Language Models with Internal and External Knowledge
item.content:encoded:
keyword: Neural language models, factual knowledge, Large Memory Language Models, pre-training, knowledge bases Summary:

Neural language models often struggle with managing factual knowledge due to the opaque nature of their parameters. The proposed Large Memory Language Models (LMLM) address this issue by storing factual information in both internal weights and an external database. By masking externally retrieved facts during training, LMLMs learn to perform targeted lookups instead of relying solely on memorization. Experimental results show that LMLMs achieve competitive performance compared to larger knowledge-dense models while offering the advantages of explicit, editable, and verifiable knowledge bases. This approach marks a significant shift in how language models handle and utilize factual knowledge, providing a more transparent and reliable way to access and update specific facts.
arXiv:2505.15962v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Neural language models are black-boxes -- both linguistic patterns and factual knowledge are distributed across billions of opaque parameters. This entangled encoding makes it difficult to reliably inspect, verify, or update specific facts. We propose a new class of language models, Large Memory Language Models (LMLM) with a pre-training recipe that stores factual knowledge in both internal weights and an external database. Our approach strategically masks externally retrieved factual values from the training loss, thereby teaching the model to perform targeted lookups rather than relying on memorization in model weights. Our experiments demonstrate that LMLMs achieve competitive performance compared to significantly larger, knowledge-dense LLMs on standard benchmarks, while offering the advantages of explicit, editable, and verifiable knowledge bases. This work represents a fundamental shift in how language models interact with and manage factual knowledge.

item.title: Explaining Puzzle Solutions in Natural Language: An Exploratory Study on 6x6 Sudoku
item.content:encoded:
explanations, Large Language Models, Sudoku, collaboration, decision-making
Summary: The study evaluates the performance of five Large Language Models (LLMs) in solving and explaining six Sudoku puzzles. While one LLM shows limited success in solving the puzzles, none of the models are able to provide explanations that reflect strategic reasoning or intuitive problem-solving. The findings highlight the challenges that need to be overcome for LLMs to become reliable partners in human-AI collaborative decision-making. The success of these models in such decision-making processes depends on their ability to offer trustworthy, gradual, and tailored explanations. The study emphasizes the importance of clear and customized explanations, especially in complex puzzle-solving scenarios like Sudoku. The inability of current LLMs to provide satisfactory explanations underscores the need for further research and development in this area.
arXiv:2505.15993v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The success of Large Language Models (LLMs) in human-AI collaborative decision-making hinges on their ability to provide trustworthy, gradual, and tailored explanations. Solving complex puzzles, such as Sudoku, offers a canonical example of this collaboration, where clear and customized explanations often hold greater importance than the final solution. In this study, we evaluate the performance of five LLMs in solving and explaining \sixsix{} Sudoku puzzles. While one LLM demonstrates limited success in solving puzzles, none can explain the solution process in a manner that reflects strategic reasoning or intuitive problem-solving. These findings underscore significant challenges that must be addressed before LLMs can become effective partners in human-AI collaborative decision-making.

item.title: Leveraging Online Data to Enhance Medical Knowledge in a Small Persian Language Model
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: language models, healthcare industry, Persian, medical knowledge, small language model
Summary:
- This study focuses on enhancing medical knowledge in small language models, particularly in low-resource languages like Persian.
- The researchers curated a dataset from online sources such as medical magazines and real doctor-patient QA pairs, making it the first of its kind in Persian.
- By fine-tuning a baseline model with their curated data, the researchers were able to improve the model's medical knowledge.
- Benchmark evaluations showed that the fine-tuned model outperformed the baseline in medical question answering accuracy and response quality.
- This work demonstrates the potential of utilizing open-access online data to enrich small language models in the medical field, providing a unique solution for Persian medical AI applications in resource-constrained environments.
Summary:
arXiv:2505.16000v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The rapid advancement of language models has demonstrated the potential of artificial intelligence in the healthcare industry. However, small language models struggle with specialized domains in low-resource languages like Persian. While numerous medical-domain websites exist in Persian, no curated dataset or corpus has been available making ours the first of its kind. This study explores the enhancement of medical knowledge in a small language model by leveraging accessible online data, including a crawled corpus from medical magazines and a dataset of real doctor-patient QA pairs. We fine-tuned a baseline model using our curated data to improve its medical knowledge. Benchmark evaluations demonstrate that the fine-tuned model achieves improved accuracy in medical question answering and provides better responses compared to its baseline. This work highlights the potential of leveraging open-access online data to enrich small language models in medical fields, providing a novel solution for Persian medical AI applications suitable for resource-constrained environments.

item.title: Causal Interventions Reveal Shared Structure Across English Filler-Gap Constructions
item.content:encoded:
<div> Keywords: Large Language Models, syntax, causal interpretability, English filler-gap dependency constructions, linguistic theory
Summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) have become valuable tools for linguists studying syntax. Causal interpretability methods applied to LLMs can enhance the evidence they provide by revealing the abstract mechanisms these models use. Through experiments using Distributed Interchange Interventions, LLMs demonstrate convergent abstract analyses of English filler-gap dependency constructions. These analyses not only confirm existing linguistic theories but also uncover overlooked factors like frequency, filler type, and context that could prompt revisions to current theories. By delving into the internal mechanisms of LLMs, new insights emerge that can advance linguistic theory in understanding syntactic structures. <div> arXiv:2505.16002v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have emerged as powerful sources of evidence for linguists seeking to develop theories of syntax. In this paper, we argue that causal interpretability methods, applied to LLMs, can greatly enhance the value of such evidence by helping us characterize the abstract mechanisms that LLMs learn to use. Our empirical focus is a set of English filler-gap dependency constructions (e.g., questions, relative clauses). Linguistic theories largely agree that these constructions share many properties. Using experiments based in Distributed Interchange Interventions, we show that LLMs converge on similar abstract analyses of these constructions. These analyses also reveal previously overlooked factors -- relating to frequency, filler type, and surrounding context -- that could motivate changes to standard linguistic theory. Overall, these results suggest that mechanistic, internal analyses of LLMs can push linguistic theory forward.

item.title: SLMEval: Entropy-Based Calibration for Human-Aligned Evaluation of Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
calibration, language models, SLMEval, human judgments, correlation

Summary:
The article introduces the LLM-as-a-Judge paradigm for evaluating language models and discusses calibration techniques for aligning evaluators with human judgment. However, existing calibration methods have shown limitations in real-world, open-ended tasks. The study introduces SLMEval, a novel calibration method based on entropy maximization using a small amount of human preference data. This approach reweights evaluator scores to achieve strong correlation with human evaluations in two real-world production use cases and a public benchmark. For instance, SLMEval outperforms G-eval by achieving a Spearman correlation of 0.57 with human judgments on a specific task. In addition, SLMEval reduces evaluation costs significantly compared to GPT-4-based calibrated evaluators like G-eval.
arXiv:2505.16003v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The LLM-as-a-Judge paradigm offers a scalable, reference-free approach for evaluating language models. Although several calibration techniques have been proposed to better align these evaluators with human judgment, prior studies focus primarily on narrow, well-structured benchmarks. As a result, it remains unclear whether such calibrations generalize to real-world, open-ended tasks. In this work, we show that SOTA calibrated evaluators often fail in these settings, exhibiting weak or even negative correlation with human judgments. To address this, we propose SLMEval, a novel and efficient calibration method based on entropy maximization over a small amount of human preference data. By estimating a latent distribution over model quality and reweighting evaluator scores accordingly, SLMEval achieves strong correlation with human evaluations across two real-world production use cases and the public benchmark. For example, on one such task, SLMEval achieves a Spearman correlation of 0.57 with human judgments, while G-Eval yields a negative correlation. In addition, SLMEval reduces evaluation costs by 5-30x compared to GPT-4-based calibrated evaluators such as G-eval.

item.title: LAGO: Few-shot Crosslingual Embedding Inversion Attacks via Language Similarity-Aware Graph Optimization
item.content:encoded:
<div> graph optimization, few-shot, cross-lingual, embedding inversion attacks, privacy vulnerabilities
Summary: The proposed LAGO approach addresses privacy vulnerabilities in multilingual NLP systems through few-shot cross-lingual embedding inversion attacks. It models linguistic relationships using a graph-based constrained distributed optimization framework, integrating syntactic and lexical similarity as edge constraints for collaborative parameter learning across related languages. The method generalizes prior approaches and includes Frobenius-norm regularization with linear inequality or total variation constraints for robust alignment of cross-lingual embedding spaces with limited data. Extensive experiments show that LAGO significantly improves attack transferability, highlighting the importance of language similarity in privacy-preserving multilingual embeddings.
Summary: <div> arXiv:2505.16008v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We propose LAGO - Language Similarity-Aware Graph Optimization - a novel approach for few-shot cross-lingual embedding inversion attacks, addressing critical privacy vulnerabilities in multilingual NLP systems. Unlike prior work in embedding inversion attacks that treat languages independently, LAGO explicitly models linguistic relationships through a graph-based constrained distributed optimization framework. By integrating syntactic and lexical similarity as edge constraints, our method enables collaborative parameter learning across related languages. Theoretically, we show this formulation generalizes prior approaches, such as ALGEN, which emerges as a special case when similarity constraints are relaxed. Our framework uniquely combines Frobenius-norm regularization with linear inequality or total variation constraints, ensuring robust alignment of cross-lingual embedding spaces even with extremely limited data (as few as 10 samples per language). Extensive experiments across multiple languages and embedding models demonstrate that LAGO substantially improves the transferability of attacks with 10-20% increase in Rouge-L score over baselines. This work establishes language similarity as a critical factor in inversion attack transferability, urging renewed focus on language-aware privacy-preserving multilingual embeddings.

item.title: Ranking Free RAG: Replacing Re-ranking with Selection in RAG for Sensitive Domains
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Retrieval-Augmented Generation, METEORA, Rationales, Adversarial Content, Explainability

Summary:
Traditional Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipelines are limited by heuristic-based retrieval and lack of explainability and robustness against adversarial content. METEORA, a novel method, replaces re-ranking in RAG with a rationale-driven selection approach. It uses general-purpose LLMs to generate rationales that guide evidence chunk selection in a three-stage process. This eliminates the need for top-k heuristics and enhances generation accuracy by 33.34% while using fewer chunks. METEORA also includes a Verifier LLM for consistency checks to detect and filter poisoned content, improving resilience to poisoning attacks. Overall, METEORA improves explainability, interpretability, generation accuracy, and resilience to adversarial content in RAG pipelines.
arXiv:2505.16014v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Traditional Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipelines rely on similarity-based retrieval and re-ranking, which depend on heuristics such as top-k, and lack explainability, interpretability, and robustness against adversarial content. To address this gap, we propose a novel method METEORA that replaces re-ranking in RAG with a rationale-driven selection approach. METEORA operates in two stages. First, a general-purpose LLM is preference-tuned to generate rationales conditioned on the input query using direct preference optimization. These rationales guide the evidence chunk selection engine, which selects relevant chunks in three stages: pairing individual rationales with corresponding retrieved chunks for local relevance, global selection with elbow detection for adaptive cutoff, and context expansion via neighboring chunks. This process eliminates the need for top-k heuristics. The rationales are also used for consistency check using a Verifier LLM to detect and filter poisoned or misleading content for safe generation. The framework provides explainable and interpretable evidence flow by using rationales consistently across both selection and verification. Our evaluation across six datasets spanning legal, financial, and academic research domains shows that METEORA improves generation accuracy by 33.34% while using approximately 50% fewer chunks than state-of-the-art re-ranking methods. In adversarial settings, METEORA significantly improves the F1 score from 0.10 to 0.44 over the state-of-the-art perplexity-based defense baseline, demonstrating strong resilience to poisoning attacks. Code available at: https://anonymous.4open.science/r/METEORA-DC46/README.md

item.title: NOVER: Incentive Training for Language Models via Verifier-Free Reinforcement Learning
item.content:encoded:
<div> Keywords: incentive training, reinforcement learning, language models, text-to-text tasks, NOVER
Summary: NOVER is a new reinforcement learning framework that does not require an external verifier, making it applicable to text-to-text tasks without the need for high-quality annotated data. It surpasses models distilled from large reasoning models like DeepSeek R1 671B by 7.7 percent. NOVER introduces the concept of inverse incentive training and provides flexibility in optimizing large language models to improve performance across a wide range of tasks. By focusing on the final answer part of a language model's output, NOVER promotes the generation of intermediate reasoning steps, enhancing the model's overall performance in various domains. <div> arXiv:2505.16022v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advances such as DeepSeek R1-Zero highlight the effectiveness of incentive training, a reinforcement learning paradigm that computes rewards solely based on the final answer part of a language model's output, thereby encouraging the generation of intermediate reasoning steps. However, these methods fundamentally rely on external verifiers, which limits their applicability to domains like mathematics and coding where such verifiers are readily available. Although reward models can serve as verifiers, they require high-quality annotated data and are costly to train. In this work, we propose NOVER, NO-VERifier Reinforcement Learning, a general reinforcement learning framework that requires only standard supervised fine-tuning data with no need for an external verifier. NOVER enables incentive training across a wide range of text-to-text tasks and outperforms the model of the same size distilled from large reasoning models such as DeepSeek R1 671B by 7.7 percent. Moreover, the flexibility of NOVER enables new possibilities for optimizing large language models, such as inverse incentive training.

item.title: Prototypical Human-AI Collaboration Behaviors from LLM-Assisted Writing in the Wild
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, collaborative behavior, user interaction, writing tasks, AI assistants Summary: This article presents a large-scale analysis of collaborative behavior between users and large language models (LLMs) during writing tasks with AI assistants such as Bing Copilot and WildChat. The study identifies Prototypical Human-AI Collaboration Behaviors (PATHs) that represent common ways users interact with LLMs, including revising intents, exploring texts, posing questions, adjusting style, and injecting new content. These PATHs explain the majority of variation in user-LLM interactions and are correlated with specific writing intents. The findings highlight how users actively refine, explore, and co-construct text with LLMs, indicating a shift from passive acceptance of output. The study suggests implications for improving LLM alignment with user needs.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.16023v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: As large language models (LLMs) are used in complex writing workflows, users engage in multi-turn interactions to steer generations to better fit their needs. Rather than passively accepting output, users actively refine, explore, and co-construct text. We conduct a large-scale analysis of this collaborative behavior for users engaged in writing tasks in the wild with two popular AI assistants, Bing Copilot and WildChat. Our analysis goes beyond simple task classification or satisfaction estimation common in prior work and instead characterizes how users interact with LLMs through the course of a session. We identify prototypical behaviors in how users interact with LLMs in prompts following their original request. We refer to these as Prototypical Human-AI Collaboration Behaviors (PATHs) and find that a small group of PATHs explain a majority of the variation seen in user-LLM interaction. These PATHs span users revising intents, exploring texts, posing questions, adjusting style or injecting new content. Next, we find statistically significant correlations between specific writing intents and PATHs, revealing how users' intents shape their collaboration behaviors. We conclude by discussing the implications of our findings on LLM alignment.

item.title: OpenEthics: A Comprehensive Ethical Evaluation of Open-Source Generative Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, ethical evaluation, safety, fairness, reliability Summary: Generative large language models have the potential for significant impact, but also raise ethical concerns. This study provides a broad ethical evaluation of 29 recent open-source large language models across four aspects: Robustness, reliability, safety, and fairness. The assessment was conducted in both English and Turkish languages to ensure diversity in language coverage. The results show that many open-source models prioritize safety and fairness, with good robustness but concerns remain regarding reliability. Ethical evaluation can effectively be done independently of language used. Models with larger parameter counts tend to exhibit better ethical performance. The Gemma and Qwen models are highlighted as demonstrating the most ethical behavior among those evaluated. This study aims to guide safer model development by addressing gaps in evaluation breadth, language coverage, and model diversity.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.16036v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Generative large language models present significant potential but also raise critical ethical concerns. Most studies focus on narrow ethical dimensions, and also limited diversity of languages and models. To address these gaps, we conduct a broad ethical evaluation of 29 recent open-source large language models using a novel data collection including four ethical aspects: Robustness, reliability, safety, and fairness. We analyze model behavior in both a commonly used language, English, and a low-resource language, Turkish. Our aim is to provide a comprehensive ethical assessment and guide safer model development by filling existing gaps in evaluation breadth, language coverage, and model diversity. Our experimental results, based on LLM-as-a-Judge, reveal that optimization efforts for many open-source models appear to have prioritized safety and fairness, and demonstrated good robustness while reliability remains a concern. We demonstrate that ethical evaluation can be effectively conducted independently of the language used. In addition, models with larger parameter counts tend to exhibit better ethical performance, with Gemma and Qwen models demonstrating the most ethical behavior among those evaluated.

item.title: Internal and External Impacts of Natural Language Processing Papers
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: NLP research, top-tier conferences, citations, language modeling, societal implications Summary: - The study analyzes the impact of NLP research published in prestigious conferences from 1979 to 2024. - Citations from research articles and external sources like patents, media, and policy documents are examined to understand the consumption of NLP topics within academia and the wider public. - Language modeling emerges as the most influential topic both internally within the academic community and externally in the broader public sphere. - Areas such as linguistic foundations have lower impacts in comparison. - Topics like ethics, bias, and fairness receive significant attention in policy documents but have fewer academic citations, highlighting a divergence in focus between academia and societal impact. - External domains, such as patents, prioritize practical NLP applications, while media and policy documents engage more with the societal implications of NLP models.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.16061v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We investigate the impacts of NLP research published in top-tier conferences (i.e., ACL, EMNLP, and NAACL) from 1979 to 2024. By analyzing citations from research articles and external sources such as patents, media, and policy documents, we examine how different NLP topics are consumed both within the academic community and by the broader public. Our findings reveal that language modeling has the widest internal and external influence, while linguistic foundations have lower impacts. We also observe that internal and external impacts generally align, but topics like ethics, bias, and fairness show significant attention in policy documents with much fewer academic citations. Additionally, external domains exhibit distinct preferences, with patents focusing on practical NLP applications and media and policy documents engaging more with the societal implications of NLP models.

item.title: Small Language Models in the Real World: Insights from Industrial Text Classification
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: ChatGPT, Transformer models, text classification, prompt engineering, supervised fine-tuning
Summary:
The paper evaluates prompt engineering and supervised fine-tuning methods for transformer-based text classification, focusing on industrial scenarios like email classification, legal document categorization, and classifying long academic texts. Decoder-only models like Llama show strong performance but are inefficient in inference due to token-by-token generation. The effectiveness of smaller language models in text classification tasks is explored, with attention to performance and efficiency in Video Random-Access Memory (VRAM) utilization. The study aims to provide insights for the practical deployment of compact models in industrial settings.
arXiv:2505.16078v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: With the emergence of ChatGPT, Transformer models have significantly advanced text classification and related tasks. Decoder-only models such as Llama exhibit strong performance and flexibility, yet they suffer from inefficiency on inference due to token-by-token generation, and their effectiveness in text classification tasks heavily depends on prompt quality. Moreover, their substantial GPU resource requirements often limit widespread adoption. Thus, the question of whether smaller language models are capable of effectively handling text classification tasks emerges as a topic of significant interest. However, the selection of appropriate models and methodologies remains largely underexplored. In this paper, we conduct a comprehensive evaluation of prompt engineering and supervised fine-tuning methods for transformer-based text classification. Specifically, we focus on practical industrial scenarios, including email classification, legal document categorization, and the classification of extremely long academic texts. We examine the strengths and limitations of smaller models, with particular attention to both their performance and their efficiency in Video Random-Access Memory (VRAM) utilization, thereby providing valuable insights for the local deployment and application of compact models in industrial settings.

item.title: BiasLab: Toward Explainable Political Bias Detection with Dual-Axis Annotations and Rationale Indicators
item.content:encoded:
political news articles, perceived ideological bias, BiasLab dataset, annotation schema, explainable modeling Summary: The article introduces BiasLab, a dataset of 300 political news articles annotated for perceived ideological bias. The dataset includes labels for sentiment toward the Democratic and Republican parties, enriched with rationale indicators. The annotation pipeline incorporates worker qualification and has been refined through analysis. The inter-annotator agreement is quantified, misalignment with source-level outlet bias is analyzed, and labels are organized into interpretable subsets. Simulation using GPT-4o shows mirrored asymmetries in misclassifying subtly right-leaning content. Two modeling tasks are defined: perception drift prediction and rationale type classification, with baseline performance reported. Rich rationale annotations aim to facilitate explainable modeling of political bias. The dataset, annotation schema, and modeling code are released to encourage research on explanation effectiveness in NLP systems.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.16081v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We present BiasLab, a dataset of 300 political news articles annotated for perceived ideological bias. These articles were selected from a curated 900-document pool covering diverse political events and source biases. Each article is labeled by crowdworkers along two independent scales, assessing sentiment toward the Democratic and Republican parties, and enriched with rationale indicators. The annotation pipeline incorporates targeted worker qualification and was refined through pilot-phase analysis. We quantify inter-annotator agreement, analyze misalignment with source-level outlet bias, and organize the resulting labels into interpretable subsets. Additionally, we simulate annotation using schema-constrained GPT-4o, enabling direct comparison to human labels and revealing mirrored asymmetries, especially in misclassifying subtly right-leaning content. We define two modeling tasks: perception drift prediction and rationale type classification, and report baseline performance to illustrate the challenge of explainable bias detection. BiasLab's rich rationale annotations provide actionable interpretations that facilitate explainable modeling of political bias, supporting the development of transparent, socially aware NLP systems. We release the dataset, annotation schema, and modeling code to encourage research on human-in-the-loop interpretability and the evaluation of explanation effectiveness in real-world settings.

item.title: Date Fragments: A Hidden Bottleneck of Tokenization for Temporal Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: BPE tokenizers, date fragmentation ratio, DateAugBench, temporal reasoning, language models
Summary:
1. The study addresses the issue of modern BPE tokenizers splitting calendar dates into meaningless fragments, affecting temporal reasoning accuracy. 2. The authors introduce the date fragmentation ratio metric to measure how well tokenizers preserve multi-digit date components. 3. DateAugBench, a dataset with 6500 examples across various temporal reasoning tasks, is released to evaluate tokenizer performance. 4. Through experimentation, the study reveals an emergent date-abstraction mechanism in large language models that stitch together date fragments for reasoning. 5. Results show that excessive fragmentation leads to accuracy drops, especially on uncommon dates like historical or futuristic ones. 6. The study highlights that the larger the language model, the quicker it is at performing date abstraction to rectify fragmented dates. 7. Additionally, the research uncovers a distinct reasoning path followed by language models when assembling date fragments, which may differ from human interpretation.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.16088v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Modern BPE tokenizers often split calendar dates into meaningless fragments, e.g., 20250312 $\rightarrow$ 202, 503, 12, inflating token counts and obscuring the inherent structure needed for robust temporal reasoning. In this work, we (1) introduce a simple yet interpretable metric, termed date fragmentation ratio, that measures how faithfully a tokenizer preserves multi-digit date components; (2) release DateAugBench, a suite of 6500 examples spanning three temporal reasoning tasks: context-based date resolution, format-invariance puzzles, and date arithmetic across historical, contemporary, and future regimes; and (3) through layer-wise probing and causal attention-hop analyses, uncover an emergent date-abstraction mechanism whereby large language models stitch together the fragments of month, day, and year components for temporal reasoning. Our experiments show that excessive fragmentation correlates with accuracy drops of up to 10 points on uncommon dates like historical and futuristic dates. Further, we find that the larger the model, the faster the emergent date abstraction that heals date fragments is accomplished. Lastly, we observe a reasoning path that LLMs follow to assemble date fragments, typically differing from human interpretation (year $\rightarrow$ month $\rightarrow$ day).

item.title: Continually Self-Improving Language Models for Bariatric Surgery Question--Answering
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: bariatric surgery, healthcare disparities, bRAGgen, adaptive retrieval-augmented generation, patient engagement
Summary: bRAGgen, an adaptive retrieval-augmented generation model, addresses healthcare disparities in bariatric surgery by integrating real-time medical evidence to provide accurate information. Patient engagement with multidisciplinary providers is crucial for successful bariatric and metabolic surgery (MBS) outcomes. Access barriers hinder the patient journey, but bRAGq, a dataset of bariatric surgery-related questions, aims to bridge this gap. The model surpasses state-of-the-art models in generating clinically accurate responses, validated by an expert bariatric surgeon. Effective longitudinal care, from preoperative preparation to postoperative management, can be facilitated by bRAGgen's self-updating architecture.Enhancing patient access to evidence-based information is essential in optimizing MBS treatment effectiveness. Healthcare disparities can be mitigated through innovative models like bRAGgen, ensuring accurate and timely information exchange between patients and healthcare providers.

arXiv:2505.16102v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: While bariatric and metabolic surgery (MBS) is considered the gold standard treatment for severe and morbid obesity, its therapeutic efficacy hinges upon active and longitudinal engagement with multidisciplinary providers, including surgeons, dietitians/nutritionists, psychologists, and endocrinologists. This engagement spans the entire patient journey, from preoperative preparation to long-term postoperative management. However, this process is often hindered by numerous healthcare disparities, such as logistical and access barriers, which impair easy patient access to timely, evidence-based, clinician-endorsed information. To address these gaps, we introduce bRAGgen, a novel adaptive retrieval-augmented generation (RAG)-based model that autonomously integrates real-time medical evidence when response confidence dips below dynamic thresholds. This self-updating architecture ensures that responses remain current and accurate, reducing the risk of misinformation. Additionally, we present bRAGq, a curated dataset of 1,302 bariatric surgery--related questions, validated by an expert bariatric surgeon. bRAGq constitutes the first large-scale, domain-specific benchmark for comprehensive MBS care. In a two-phase evaluation, bRAGgen is benchmarked against state-of-the-art models using both large language model (LLM)--based metrics and expert surgeon review. Across all evaluation dimensions, bRAGgen demonstrates substantially superior performance in generating clinically accurate and relevant responses.

item.title: Hierarchical Safety Realignment: Lightweight Restoration of Safety in Pruned Large Vision-Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Hierarchical Safety Realignment, LVLMs, network pruning, safety performance, attention heads

Summary: The article introduces a novel approach, Hierarchical Safety Realignment (HSR), to address the issue of safety performance degradation in Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) post-network pruning. HSR quantifies the contribution of each attention head to safety and selectively restores critical neurons within these attention heads to hierarchically realign safety. This process progresses from the attention head level to the neuron level, enhancing safety performance across various models and pruning strategies. HSR stands out as the first work explicitly focused on restoring safety in LVLMs after pruning, offering notable improvements in safety performance.
arXiv:2505.16104v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: With the increasing size of Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs), network pruning techniques aimed at compressing models for deployment in resource-constrained environments have garnered significant attention. However, we observe that pruning often leads to a degradation in safety performance. To address this issue, we present a novel and lightweight approach, termed Hierarchical Safety Realignment (HSR). HSR operates by first quantifying the contribution of each attention head to safety, identifying the most critical ones, and then selectively restoring neurons directly within these attention heads that play a pivotal role in maintaining safety. This process hierarchically realigns the safety of pruned LVLMs, progressing from the attention head level to the neuron level. We validate HSR across various models and pruning strategies, consistently achieving notable improvements in safety performance. To our knowledge, this is the first work explicitly focused on restoring safety in LVLMs post-pruning.

item.title: MPL: Multiple Programming Languages with Large Language Models for Information Extraction
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Information Extraction, Programming Languages, Structured Output Generation, Supervised Fine-Tuning, Large Language Models Summary: Multiple Programming Languages with large language models (MPL) is a novel framework for information extraction that explores the potential of using different programming languages during the supervised fine-tuning phase. The framework introduces the use of function-prompt with virtual running to simulate code-style inputs effectively and efficiently. Experimental results on various datasets show the effectiveness of MPL in structured output generation tasks. The framework is designed to leverage the structural advantages of programming languages over natural languages for information extraction. Extensive analysis and experiments have been conducted to demonstrate the benefits of incorporating multiple programming languages during the fine-tuning process. The released code allows for further research and development in this area.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.16107v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent research in information extraction (IE) focuses on utilizing code-style inputs to enhance structured output generation. The intuition behind this is that the programming languages (PLs) inherently exhibit greater structural organization than natural languages (NLs). This structural advantage makes PLs particularly suited for IE tasks. Nevertheless, existing research primarily focuses on Python for code-style simulation, overlooking the potential of other widely-used PLs (e.g., C++ and Java) during the supervised fine-tuning (SFT) phase. In this research, we propose \textbf{M}ultiple \textbf{P}rogramming \textbf{L}anguages with large language models for information extraction (abbreviated as \textbf{MPL}), a novel framework that explores the potential of incorporating different PLs in the SFT phase. Additionally, we introduce \texttt{function-prompt} with virtual running to simulate code-style inputs more effectively and efficiently. Experimental results on a wide range of datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of MPL. Furthermore, we conduct extensive experiments to provide a comprehensive analysis. We have released our code for future research.

item.title: Semiotic Reconstruction of Destination Expectation Constructs An LLM-Driven Computational Paradigm for Social Media Tourism Analytics
item.content:encoded:
<div> methods, travel decisions, user-generated content, social media, expectation extraction
Summary: This study introduces a dual-method LLM framework for analyzing user-generated content (UGC) in social media for travel decisions. By combining unsupervised expectation extraction with supervised fine-tuning informed by surveys, the framework reveals that leisure and social expectations are key drivers of engagement in UGC, more so than foundational natural and emotional factors. The study establishes LLMs as precision tools for quantifying expectations, advancing tourism analytics methodology. It also proposes targeted strategies for personalized experiences and social travel promotion. The framework's adaptability extends to consumer behavior research, showcasing the transformative potential of computational social science in optimizing marketing strategies. <div> arXiv:2505.16118v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Social media's rise establishes user-generated content (UGC) as pivotal for travel decisions, yet analytical methods lack scalability. This study introduces a dual-method LLM framework: unsupervised expectation extraction from UGC paired with survey-informed supervised fine-tuning. Findings reveal leisure/social expectations drive engagement more than foundational natural/emotional factors. By establishing LLMs as precision tools for expectation quantification, we advance tourism analytics methodology and propose targeted strategies for experience personalization and social travel promotion. The framework's adaptability extends to consumer behavior research, demonstrating computational social science's transformative potential in marketing optimization.

item.title: KoBALT: Korean Benchmark For Advanced Linguistic Tasks
item.content:encoded:
Benchmark, Korean, linguistic tasks, large language models, evaluation

Summary: The paper introduces KoBALT, a comprehensive linguistic benchmark for evaluating large language models in Korean. It consists of 700 multiple-choice questions across five linguistic domains: syntax, semantics, pragmatics, phonetics/phonology, and morphology. KoBALT addresses the limitations of conventional benchmarks by providing linguistically motivated questions with minimal n-gram overlap with standard Korean corpora to prevent data contamination. Evaluation of 20 LLMs shows varying performance across linguistic domains, with the highest achieving 61% general accuracy. Human preference evaluation validates KoBALT's effectiveness in assessing Korean language understanding. The benchmark aims to bridge the gap in linguistic evaluation for diverse languages and offers a robust framework for evaluating linguistic competence in Korean language models.

arXiv:2505.16125v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce KoBALT (Korean Benchmark for Advanced Linguistic Tasks), a comprehensive linguistically-motivated benchmark comprising 700 multiple-choice questions spanning 24 phenomena across five linguistic domains: syntax, semantics, pragmatics, phonetics/phonology, and morphology. KoBALT is designed to advance the evaluation of large language models (LLMs) in Korean, a morphologically rich language, by addressing the limitations of conventional benchmarks that often lack linguistic depth and typological grounding. It introduces a suite of expert-curated, linguistically motivated questions with minimal n-gram overlap with standard Korean corpora, substantially mitigating the risk of data contamination and allowing a more robust assessment of true language understanding. Our evaluation of 20 contemporary LLMs reveals significant performance disparities, with the highest-performing model achieving 61\% general accuracy but showing substantial variation across linguistic domains - from stronger performance in semantics (66\%) to considerable weaknesses in phonology (31\%) and morphology (36\%). Through human preference evaluation with 95 annotators, we demonstrate a strong correlation between KoBALT scores and human judgments, validating our benchmark's effectiveness as a discriminative measure of Korean language understanding. KoBALT addresses critical gaps in linguistic evaluation for typologically diverse languages and provides a robust framework for assessing genuine linguistic competence in Korean language models.

item.title: Veracity Bias and Beyond: Uncovering LLMs' Hidden Beliefs in Problem-Solving Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
veracity, biases, LLMs, demographics, solutions
Summary: This study examines the biases present in Large Language Models (LLMs) regarding the association of solution veracity with demographics. Two types of biases were identified: Attribution Bias, where correct solutions are disproportionately attributed to certain demographic groups, and Evaluation Bias, where models assess solutions differently based on perceived author demographics. The experiments conducted on five value-aligned LLMs revealed consistent biases: African-American groups were given fewer correct solutions in math and coding tasks, while Asian authorships were least favored in writing evaluations. The models also automatically assigned racially stereotypical colors to demographic groups in visualization code, indicating deeply embedded biases in their reasoning processes. These findings highlight the need for caution in deploying LLMs in educational and evaluation settings due to the pervasive demographic biases present.
arXiv:2505.16128v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Despite LLMs' explicit alignment against demographic stereotypes, they have been shown to exhibit biases under various social contexts. In this work, we find that LLMs exhibit concerning biases in how they associate solution veracity with demographics. Through experiments across five human value-aligned LLMs on mathematics, coding, commonsense, and writing problems, we reveal two forms of such veracity biases: Attribution Bias, where models disproportionately attribute correct solutions to certain demographic groups, and Evaluation Bias, where models' assessment of identical solutions varies based on perceived demographic authorship. Our results show pervasive biases: LLMs consistently attribute fewer correct solutions and more incorrect ones to African-American groups in math and coding, while Asian authorships are least preferred in writing evaluation. In additional studies, we show LLMs automatically assign racially stereotypical colors to demographic groups in visualization code, suggesting these biases are deeply embedded in models' reasoning processes. Our findings indicate that demographic bias extends beyond surface-level stereotypes and social context provocations, raising concerns about LLMs' deployment in educational and evaluation settings.

item.title: LLMs Are Not Scorers: Rethinking MT Evaluation with Generation-Based Methods
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, machine translation quality estimation, generation-based evaluation, semantic similarity scoring, hybrid approaches
Summary:
Recent studies have explored the application of large language models (LLMs) in machine translation quality estimation (MTQE) by utilizing direct scoring methods, but these approaches often show low correlation with human judgments at the segment level. This paper introduces a generation-based evaluation paradigm that uses decoder-only LLMs to generate high-quality references, followed by semantic similarity scoring with sentence embeddings. The study conducted a comprehensive evaluation across 8 LLMs and 8 language pairs, demonstrating that the proposed method outperforms intra-LLM direct scoring baselines and external non-LLM reference-free metrics from MTME. The results highlight the effectiveness of generation-based evaluation and suggest a shift towards hybrid approaches that combine fluent generation with accurate semantic assessment.
arXiv:2505.16129v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent studies have applied large language models (LLMs) to machine translation quality estimation (MTQE) by prompting models to assign numeric scores. Nonetheless, these direct scoring methods tend to show low segment-level correlation with human judgments. In this paper, we propose a generation-based evaluation paradigm that leverages decoder-only LLMs to produce high-quality references, followed by semantic similarity scoring using sentence embeddings. We conduct the most extensive evaluation to date in MTQE, covering 8 LLMs and 8 language pairs. Empirical results show that our method outperforms both intra-LLM direct scoring baselines and external non-LLM reference-free metrics from MTME. These findings demonstrate the strength of generation-based evaluation and support a shift toward hybrid approaches that combine fluent generation with accurate semantic assessment.

item.title: Position of Uncertainty: A Cross-Linguistic Study of Positional Bias in Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
positional bias, model uncertainty, syntax, prompting, language diversity, language models Positional bias in large language models varies across different languages, with the Qwen2.5-7B model showing a preference for late positions instead of the expected early-token bias. Explicit positional guidance reduces accuracy in all languages, challenging common prompt-engineering practices. Aligning context with positional bias increases entropy but does not predict accuracy reliably. Language models impose dominant word order even in free-word-order languages like Hindi. This cross-linguistic study sheds light on how positional bias interacts with model uncertainty, syntax, and prompting, revealing language-specific variations and challenging assumptions about language processing in large language models.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.16134v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models exhibit positional bias -- systematic neglect of information at specific context positions -- yet its interplay with linguistic diversity remains poorly understood. We present a cross-linguistic study across five typologically distinct languages (English, Russian, German, Hindi, Vietnamese), examining how positional bias interacts with model uncertainty, syntax, and prompting. Key findings: (1) Positional bias is model-driven, with language-specific variations -- Qwen2.5-7B favors late positions, challenging assumptions of early-token bias; (2) Explicit positional guidance (e.g., correct context is at position X) reduces accuracy across languages, undermining prompt-engineering practices; (3) Aligning context with positional bias increases entropy, yet minimal entropy does not predict accuracy. (4) We further uncover that LLMs differently impose dominant word order in free-word-order languages like Hindi.

item.title: Distilling the Implicit Multi-Branch Structure in LLMs' Reasoning via Reinforcement Learning
item.content:encoded:
fine-tuning, Large Language Models (LLMs), meta-reasoning, reinforcement learning, distillation Summary: The article introduces a novel approach, RLKD, for distilling reasoning paths from teacher to student models in Large Language Models (LLMs). The current method of supervised fine-tuning (SFT) often lacks the complexity of authentic reasoning paths, which involve meta-reasoning and solving within a multi-branch structure. RLKD proposes a reinforcement learning (RL)-based framework guided by a Generative Structure Reward Model (GSRM) to capture this rich reasoning structure. By converting reasoning paths into meta-reasoning-solving steps, RLKD allows student LLMs to internalize the teacher's implicit reasoning structure. Experiments demonstrate that RLKD outperforms traditional SFT-RL pipelines, even with minimal training data, highlighting the potential for enhanced student reasoning through this new approach.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.16142v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Distilling reasoning paths from teacher to student models via supervised fine-tuning (SFT) provides a shortcut for improving the reasoning ability of smaller Large Language Models (LLMs). However, the reasoning paths generated by teacher models often reflect only surface-level traces of their underlying authentic reasoning. Insights from cognitive neuroscience suggest that authentic reasoning involves a complex interweaving between meta-reasoning (which selects appropriate sub-problems from multiple candidates) and solving (which addresses the sub-problem). This implies authentic reasoning has an implicit multi-branch structure. Supervised fine-tuning collapses this rich structure into a flat sequence of token prediction in the teacher's reasoning path, preventing effective distillation of this structure to students. To address this limitation, we propose RLKD, a reinforcement learning (RL)-based distillation framework guided by a novel Generative Structure Reward Model (GSRM). Our GSRM converts reasoning paths into multiple meta-reasoning-solving steps and computes rewards to measure structural alignment between student and teacher reasoning. RLKD combines this reward with RL, enabling student LLMs to internalize the teacher's implicit multi-branch reasoning structure rather than merely mimicking fixed output paths. Experiments show RLKD surpasses standard SFT-RL pipelines even when trained on 0.1% of data under an RL-only regime, unlocking greater student reasoning potential than SFT-based distillation.

item.title: EduBench: A Comprehensive Benchmarking Dataset for Evaluating Large Language Models in Diverse Educational Scenarios
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: language models, educational scenarios, benchmark, evaluation metrics, human annotation

Summary: This paper introduces a diverse benchmark tailored for educational scenarios, incorporating synthetic data with over 4,000 distinct educational contexts. It proposes multi-dimensional evaluation metrics covering 12 critical aspects relevant to teachers and students. Human annotation is utilized to validate the model-generated evaluation responses. A small-scale model trained on the dataset demonstrates comparable performance to state-of-the-art large models on the test set. The work lays a practical foundation for the development and evaluation of education-centric language models. The code and data are available on GitHub at https://github.com/ybai-nlp/EduBench.
arXiv:2505.16160v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: As large language models continue to advance, their application in educational contexts remains underexplored and under-optimized. In this paper, we address this gap by introducing the first diverse benchmark tailored for educational scenarios, incorporating synthetic data containing 9 major scenarios and over 4,000 distinct educational contexts. To enable comprehensive assessment, we propose a set of multi-dimensional evaluation metrics that cover 12 critical aspects relevant to both teachers and students. We further apply human annotation to ensure the effectiveness of the model-generated evaluation responses. Additionally, we succeed to train a relatively small-scale model on our constructed dataset and demonstrate that it can achieve performance comparable to state-of-the-art large models (e.g., Deepseek V3, Qwen Max) on the test set. Overall, this work provides a practical foundation for the development and evaluation of education-oriented language models. Code and data are released at https://github.com/ybai-nlp/EduBench.

item.title: KNN-SSD: Enabling Dynamic Self-Speculative Decoding via Nearest Neighbor Layer Set Optimization
item.content:encoded:
skip layers, domain shifts, language models, speculative decoding, K-Nearest Neighbor

In this article, the authors introduce KNN-SSD, an algorithm designed to enhance the domain generalizability of Self-Speculative Decoding (SSD) in large language models (LLMs). They observe that drafting with layer skipping in SSD can be sensitive to domain shifts, resulting in a drop in acceleration performance. By leveraging K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN) search, KNN-SSD matches different skipped layers with various domain inputs, leading to a 1.3x-1.6x speedup in LLM inference across multiple tasks and models. This algorithm aims to address the limitations of SSD and improve the efficiency of LLM inference in real-world applications.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.16162v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Speculative Decoding (SD) has emerged as a widely used paradigm to accelerate the inference of large language models (LLMs) without compromising generation quality. It works by efficiently drafting multiple tokens using a compact model and then verifying them in parallel using the target LLM. Notably, Self-Speculative Decoding proposes skipping certain layers to construct the draft model, which eliminates the need for additional parameters or training. Despite its strengths, we observe in this work that drafting with layer skipping exhibits significant sensitivity to domain shifts, leading to a substantial drop in acceleration performance. To enhance the domain generalizability of this paradigm, we introduce KNN-SSD, an algorithm that leverages K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN) search to match different skipped layers with various domain inputs. We evaluated our algorithm in various models and multiple tasks, observing that its application leads to 1.3x-1.6x speedup in LLM inference.

item.title: Can LLMs Simulate Human Behavioral Variability? A Case Study in the Phonemic Fluency Task
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large language models, phonemic fluency task, individual differences, human variability, network analyses Summary: Large language models (LLMs) are being studied as potential substitutes for human participants in cognitive tasks, such as the phonemic fluency task where words starting with a specific letter are generated. This study evaluated 34 different LLM configurations to determine their ability to approximate human behavioral variability. The results showed that while some configurations were able to match human averages and lexical preferences, none were able to capture the full extent of human variability. LLM outputs were found to be less diverse and rigid in structure compared to human responses. Additionally, network analyses revealed significant differences in retrieval structure between humans and models. These findings highlight the limitations of using LLMs to simulate human cognition and behavior.

Summary: Large language models were assessed for their ability to mimic individual differences in the phonemic fluency task, but none could fully replicate human variability. LLM outputs were less diverse and structured compared to human responses, indicating limitations in simulating human behavior and cognition. Network analyses uncovered fundamental disparities in retrieval patterns between humans and models, underscoring the challenges in using LLMs as substitutes for human participants in cognitive tasks.
arXiv:2505.16164v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly explored as substitutes for human participants in cognitive tasks, but their ability to simulate human behavioral variability remains unclear. This study examines whether LLMs can approximate individual differences in the phonemic fluency task, where participants generate words beginning with a target letter. We evaluated 34 model configurations, varying prompt specificity, sampling temperature, and model type, and compared outputs to responses from 106 human participants. While some configurations, especially Claude 3.7 Sonnet, matched human averages and lexical preferences, none reproduced the scope of human variability. LLM outputs were consistently less diverse and structurally rigid, and LLM ensembles failed to increase diversity. Network analyses further revealed fundamental differences in retrieval structure between humans and models. These results highlight key limitations in using LLMs to simulate human cognition and behavior.

item.title: When Do LLMs Admit Their Mistakes? Understanding the Role of Model Belief in Retraction
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, retraction, errors, internal belief, supervised fine-tuning
Summary:
In the study, the researchers explore how large language models (LLMs) acknowledge errors in their generated answers, defined as "retraction." They find that LLMs retract incorrect answers infrequently, often influenced by internal beliefs about the correctness of the answer. Models tend to retract answers they do not believe to be factually accurate, showing a causal relationship between internal belief and retraction behavior. Additionally, experiments show that models alter attention behavior during self-verification when they do not believe their answers. Furthermore, supervised fine-tuning significantly improves retraction performance by enhancing the model's ability to learn more accurate internal beliefs. The study provides insights into the dynamics of error acknowledgment and decision-making in LLMs, shedding light on ways to enhance their accuracy and reliability.
arXiv:2505.16170v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Can large language models (LLMs) admit their mistakes when they should know better? In this work, we define the behavior of acknowledging errors in previously generated answers as "retraction" and aim to understand when and why LLMs choose to retract. We first construct model-specific datasets to evaluate whether a model will retract an incorrect answer that contradicts its own parametric knowledge. While LLMs are capable of retraction, they do so only infrequently. We demonstrate that retraction is closely tied to previously identified indicators of models' internal belief: models fail to retract wrong answers that they "believe" to be factually correct. Steering experiments further demonstrate that internal belief causally influences model retraction. In particular, when the model does not believe its answer, this not only encourages the model to attempt to verify the answer, but also alters attention behavior during self-verification. Finally, we demonstrate that simple supervised fine-tuning significantly improves retraction performance by helping the model learn more accurate internal beliefs. Code and datasets are available on https://github.com/ayyyq/llm-retraction.

item.title: Automated Feedback Loops to Protect Text Simplification with Generative AI from Information Loss
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: health information, simplification, generative AI, missing information, text regeneration Summary: The study focuses on simplifying health information for better understanding using generative AI, but notes that crucial information may be lost in the process. They compared different approaches to detect and insert missing information into simplified text. Results showed that adding missing entities improved text regeneration, with adding all missing entities being the most effective method. This was found to be better than adding top-ranked entities or random words. The study used cosine similarity and ROUGE scores to evaluate semantic similarity and content overlap between original, simplified, and reconstructed text. Overall, the findings suggest that identifying and adding missing entities can enhance the quality of simplified health information.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.16172v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Understanding health information is essential in achieving and maintaining a healthy life. We focus on simplifying health information for better understanding. With the availability of generative AI, the simplification process has become efficient and of reasonable quality, however, the algorithms remove information that may be crucial for comprehension. In this study, we compare generative AI to detect missing information in simplified text, evaluate its importance, and fix the text with the missing information. We collected 50 health information texts and simplified them using gpt-4-0613. We compare five approaches to identify missing elements and regenerate the text by inserting the missing elements. These five approaches involve adding missing entities and missing words in various ways: 1) adding all the missing entities, 2) adding all missing words, 3) adding the top-3 entities ranked by gpt-4-0613, and 4, 5) serving as controls for comparison, adding randomly chosen entities. We use cosine similarity and ROUGE scores to evaluate the semantic similarity and content overlap between the original, simplified, and reconstructed simplified text. We do this for both summaries and full text. Overall, we find that adding missing entities improves the text. Adding all the missing entities resulted in better text regeneration, which was better than adding the top-ranked entities or words, or random words. Current tools can identify these entities, but are not valuable in ranking them.

item.title: Understanding Fact Recall in Language Models: Why Two-Stage Training Encourages Memorization but Mixed Training Teaches Knowledge
item.content:encoded:
training strategies, fact recall, language models, mixed training, shared parameters
Summary: This study explores how different training strategies affect the ability of language models (LMs) to recall factual knowledge. Traditional two-stage training, involving fact-storing examples followed by fact-recalling examples, often leads to rote memorization. In contrast, mixed training, which integrates both types of examples, has been shown to improve fact recall. The research introduces cross-task gradient trace to analyze shared parameters that are influenced by both types of examples. Results from experiments with synthetic datasets and two large models indicate that mixed training leads to a larger and more centralized set of shared parameters. This suggests that the emergence of specific parameters plays a crucial role in helping LMs generalize factual knowledge effectively across different task formulations.
arXiv:2505.16178v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Fact recall, the ability of language models (LMs) to retrieve specific factual knowledge, remains a challenging task despite their impressive general capabilities. Common training strategies often struggle to promote robust recall behavior with two-stage training, which first trains a model with fact-storing examples (e.g., factual statements) and then with fact-recalling examples (question-answer pairs), tending to encourage rote memorization rather than generalizable fact retrieval. In contrast, mixed training, which jointly uses both types of examples, has been empirically shown to improve the ability to recall facts, but the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. In this work, we investigate how these training strategies affect how model parameters are shaped during training and how these differences relate to their ability to recall facts. We introduce cross-task gradient trace to identify shared parameters, those strongly influenced by both fact-storing and fact-recalling examples. Our analysis on synthetic fact recall datasets with the Llama-3.2B and Pythia-2.8B models reveals that mixed training encouraging a larger and more centralized set of shared parameters. These findings suggest that the emergence of parameters may play a key role in enabling LMs to generalize factual knowledge across task formulations.

item.title: SAE-SSV: Supervised Steering in Sparse Representation Spaces for Reliable Control of Language Models
item.content:encoded:
<div> sparse autoencoders, supervised steering, latent representations, disentangle, semantic attributes
Summary: The paper introduces a novel supervised steering approach for large language models (LLMs) that operates in sparse, interpretable representation spaces. It uses sparse autoencoders (SAEs) to obtain sparse latent representations that aim to disentangle semantic attributes from model activations. Linear classifiers are then trained to identify task-relevant dimensions in these representations, followed by the learning of supervised steering vectors constrained to this subspace to align with desired behaviors. Experiments across sentiment, truthfulness, and politics polarity steering tasks demonstrate that the supervised steering vectors achieve higher success rates with minimal degradation in generation quality compared to existing methods. The analysis also reveals that a small subspace is sufficient for effective steering, allowing for more targeted and interpretable interventions. <div> arXiv:2505.16188v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated impressive capabilities in natural language understanding and generation, but controlling their behavior reliably remains challenging, especially in open-ended generation settings. This paper introduces a novel supervised steering approach that operates in sparse, interpretable representation spaces. We employ sparse autoencoders (SAEs)to obtain sparse latent representations that aim to disentangle semantic attributes from model activations. Then we train linear classifiers to identify a small subspace of task-relevant dimensions in latent representations. Finally, we learn supervised steering vectors constrained to this subspace, optimized to align with target behaviors. Experiments across sentiment, truthfulness, and politics polarity steering tasks with multiple LLMs demonstrate that our supervised steering vectors achieve higher success rates with minimal degradation in generation quality compared to existing methods. Further analysis reveals that a notably small subspace is sufficient for effective steering, enabling more targeted and interpretable interventions.

item.title: The Language of Interoception: Examining Embodiment and Emotion Through a Corpus of Body Part Mentions
item.content:encoded:
<div> Keywords: emotion, embodiment, language, health outcomes, NLP
Summary: The paper explores the relationship between emotion, embodiment, and everyday language by analyzing body part mentions (BPMs) in online English text. BPMs are common in personal narratives and tweets, with patterns varying by time and location. The text containing BPMs tends to be more emotionally charged, even when not explicitly describing physical reactions. The study also finds a strong correlation between body-related language and a range of poorer health outcomes. This research highlights the potential for future studies at the intersection of NLP, affective sciences, and human wellbeing. <div> arXiv:2505.16189v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper is the first investigation of the connection between emotion, embodiment, and everyday language in a large sample of natural language data. We created corpora of body part mentions (BPMs) in online English text (blog posts and tweets). This includes a subset featuring human annotations for the emotions of the person whose body part is mentioned in the text. We show that BPMs are common in personal narratives and tweets (~5% to 10% of posts include BPMs) and that their usage patterns vary markedly by time and %geographic location. Using word-emotion association lexicons and our annotated data, we show that text containing BPMs tends to be more emotionally charged, even when the BPM is not explicitly used to describe a physical reaction to the emotion in the text. Finally, we discover a strong and statistically significant correlation between body-related language and a variety of poorer health outcomes. In sum, we argue that investigating the role of body-part related words in language can open up valuable avenues of future research at the intersection of NLP, the affective sciences, and the study of human wellbeing.

item.title: An Empirical Study on Configuring In-Context Learning Demonstrations for Unleashing MLLMs' Sentimental Perception Capability
item.content:encoded:
zero-shot paradigm, Multimodal Sentiment Analysis, In-Context Learning, demonstrations, sentiment predictive bias

Summary: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have advanced to address various tasks under a zero-shot paradigm, but struggle with Multimodal Sentiment Analysis (MSA). This study extends the zero-shot paradigm to In-Context Learning (ICL) and optimizes three key factors related to demonstrations: retrieval, presentation, and distribution.
